qas.question: Who announced over the Radio that the president had been arrested?
Thousands of soldiers put their weapons down and joined what type of efforts?
The non violent protesting led the soldiers to engage in what type of behavior?
Opposing groups met to make and create what kind of democratic laws?
What group was to approve the new democratic constitution?
Who willingly fired into the nonviolent protesters?
What did students refused to do?
What was made illegal as a result of Moussa's arrest?

context: By 26 March, the growing <a2_0>refusal of <b5_0>soldiers<b5_0/> to <b6_0>fire<b6_0/><a2_0/> into the largely nonviolent protesting crowds turned into a full-scale tumult, and resulted into thousands of soldiers putting down <b7_0>their arms<b7_0/> and joining the <a1_0>pro-democracy<a1_0/> movement. That afternoon, <a0_0><b8_0>Lieutenant Colonel Amadou Toumani Touré<b8_0/><a0_0/> announced on the radio that he had arrested the dictatorial president, Moussa Traoré. As a consequence, <b9_0>opposition parties<b9_0/> were legalized and a national congress of civil and political groups met to draft a new democratic <a3_0>constitution<a3_0/> to be approved by <a4_0>a national referendum<a4_0/>.
